Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: Having just moved in, they prepare a small cake to share with nearby neighbors when they happen to meet.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story:
I had just moved into the building last week, and today I finally baked a small cake to share with my new neighbors, hoping to make a good impression. As I stepped into the hallway, cake in hand, the building’s alarm blared, echoing off the walls. My phone buzzed with a flash-flood warning—water was already pooling at the curb outside. I could hear anxious voices from behind doors, and someone shouted for help from the stairwell. 

As a neighbor, I wanted to knock on doors, introduce myself, and offer the cake, maybe even comfort those who seemed scared. But as a citizen, I felt the weight of responsibility: I should help coordinate an evacuation, check on the elderly couple on the third floor, and make sure everyone followed the emergency procedures. My heart pounded as I stood in the hallway, torn between the warmth of a friendly gesture and the urgent call to action for the safety of everyone in the building.
